text:
ADI IGNATIUS: I'm
Adi Ignatius, editor

in chief of Harvard Business
Review, and welcome to HBR Now.

This is the Harvard
Business Review show,

where we take in-depth looks
at timely topics like COVID,

racial inequality, the
US election and more.

To put them into
context, particularly,
for a global business audience.

My co-hosts are Joshua
Macht, who heads product
and innovation at HBS bar.

And Octavia Goredema, author
and career coach, and founder
of the 2010 agency.

Our special guest this
week, in a moment,
will be Noubar Afeyan.

Co-founder and chairman of
Moderna, one of the companies

that has achieved the most
promising results to date

in the race for
COVID-19 vaccine.

I'll bring him in,
in a moment, to talk

about the hunt for a
lifesaving vaccine,

about the business in
scientific, and even

political challenges
that the journal faces.

And about what we can all
expect in terms of a rollout.

Who's likely to get the
vaccine first, and when?

We invite all of
you who are watching

to send in questions for
Noubar as well, which
you can type into the comments.

But first, let's have a
word from our sponsor.
Our friends at Accenture.

WOMAN (VOICEOVER):
Change is all around us.

Shaped by technology
and human ingenuity,

we can make it work for
you and your business.

ADI IGNATIUS: And that brings
us to that moment in the show

where for, practically,
no reason at all, we

share a TikTok that captures
the moment we're all living in.
So hit it engineer Dave.
[VIDEO PLAYBACK]
[CHEERING]
[END PLAYBACK]
JOSHUA MACHT: OK.
Explain that one to me, Adi.

ADI IGNATIUS: I think it's
just-- it's a hurray 2020.
This is our year.
JOSHUA MACHT: OK.

ADI IGNATIUS: So anyway,
so let's the three of us

set up the topic a little
bit, before we get Noubar
in for our feature interview.

I'll tell you what's
on my mind, and I'm

really alarmed by the
latest covered spikes.

The US is having a really
awful new record for cases.

More than 80,000 new
cases, two days in a row.

Cold weather is going to
drive more people inside,

which seems to be where
this thing spreads the most.
And these aren't harmless cases.

Hospitalizations are up
40% over the past month.

And while the death
rate has been stable,

it tends to lag behind
the increase in cases,

meaning the news
could well get worse.

So we're truly in a race
between the dire consequences

of further infection and the
arrival of a workable vaccine.

To an extent, I understand
the American president

when he complains that
for the news media

it's COVID, COVID,
COVID all the time.

Well, you can't wish
this thing away.

It's still hard for
us all to comprehend

that we're living
through some sort
of dark, throwback nightmare.

A modern day Dickensian
global pandemic,

that in its lethality, is
touching nearly every corner
of the globe.

But there also is hope, and
we'll talk about that today.

Not that COVID will
magically disappear,

but they will come
up with a vaccine
in record speed, let's hope.

It will save millions of
lives till they get this
under control.
Octavia, what's on your mind?
OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Yeah.
I couldn't agree more, Adi.

And we have to cling
back to that hope.

Because 8.7 million cases
in the United States,

over 225,000 deaths,
this has been jarring.

And on top of all of,
that front of mind for me,

are that racial
disparities persist.

When it comes to causes
and deaths resulting

from this pandemic,
people of color

are getting sick and
dying from COVID-19,

at rates significantly
higher than our share
of the population.

So everything that
we're facing is

compounded by those
deeper issues of health

and economic inequity
in our society.
So I think you're exactly right.
There's so much to do.

So I'm clinging onto
that hope, right now.
JOSHUA MACHT: Octavia.
Adi.

You're both bringing
up things that there's

no question on my mind,
and I'm sure for a lot
of people watching.

I mean, at the same time I've
been excited about this show,
for a while.

To talk to someone
like our guest,
who is on the front lines of--
this is just amazing--

the speed to create something
that could potentially bring
an end to so much suffering.

The science behind
it, the business issue

is behind how this
all came together,

it is one of the most
fascinating stories
of our time.

I think everything you're
talking about we definitely

want to get out, along
with just when it

comes to this vaccine, what
are we even talking about?

What does safe and
effective really mean?
How will the public accept it?

What is going to unfold
over the next year.

Because it feels like
both of you, you know,

were definitely in this
moment, this dark moment,

where we're going
into this winter.

On the other hand, I think
we all need something to say,

we don't know how long
this turn is going to be.
But are we getting somewhere?

And maybe we learn a
little bit more today
about how that happens.
I don't know about you guys.

But I am super excited
to get started.
ADI IGNATIUS: All right.
Well, let's do it.

So it's my pleasure now
to formally introduce
our guest Noubar Afeyan.

He's a biochemist by training,
having earned a PhD at MIT
in that field.

He's an entrepreneur
by vocation.

20 years ago he created
flagship pioneering

to attract entrepreneurially
minded scientists

like himself to tackle
seemingly intractable problems.

Its portfolio includes
Moderna Therapeutics,

whose experimental COVID-19
vaccine candidate, made

using the company's messenger
RNA platform technology,

is among the most promising
entries in the race

to develop a vaccine
for mass use.

Noubar, as I said before,
is Moderna's chairman.

Interestingly, Harvard
Business School

has just written a case about
Moderna co-authored by Karim
Lakhani and Marco Iansiti.
So with that, welcome Noubar.
NOUBAR AFEYAN: Welcome.

Thanks for the welcome
Adi and colleagues.
And thanks for having me.

ADI IGNATIUS: Well, so
there's a lot to talk about.

So let me plunge right
in at the beginning.

And let's set the
stage a little bit.

You know, I saw that
Moderna last week

announced that it has
completed enrollment of 30,000
people in a Phase III trial.

What does-- help us
lay people understand.

What does that signify,
and what comes next?

NOUBAR AFEYAN: Well, getting
a vaccine or a therapeutic

approved requires a
certain set of [INAUDIBLE]
and regulatory processes.

In the case of a vaccine,
because of its intended use

to a broad population
of recipients,

the number of people on
which you have to do tests,

both for safety
and efficacy, tends

to be an order of magnitude
or two higher than what

one might do for say
a cancer treatment
or other such diseases.

So 30,000 is the design kind of
that was specified and agreed
upon with the FDA.

Completing the
enrollment, most of those

have now received two
doses per participant.

This is split 50-50
between placebo,

and the active one that receives
the vaccine is completely
blinded.

And so what it means is
that we are near complete

not only with enrollment but
also with the second dose.

And what awaits is then
the resulting effect

of the vaccine, as
compared to placebo,

on helping prevent disease,
helping mitigate disease,

all the different
factors that we'll

be looking for when we look
at efficacy considerations.

What comes next is a
pretty intense period

where-- during which
cases are accumulated.

That is, participants
in this trial actually

who get infected with
COVID-19, there's

a certain number
of them that have

to be impacted in order for
us to then compare the placebo

group to the active
group and see

whether there is a statistically
significant benefit.

The FDA has set as a
guidepost the 50% level

as to the effectiveness
of the vaccine.
That's a minimal point.

It could certainly
be higher than that.

And we await the data
once enough cases
have been recorded.

ADI IGNATIUS: So I mentioned
that Moderna and I think

Pfizer are well on the
path and developing
an RNA-based vaccine.

You know, others are developing
different approaches.

How-- potential
consumers like myself,

how are we supposed
to comprehend and act

on these different options
as they become available?

NOUBAR AFEYAN: Well, I
mean it's a good question.

Because we're in
uncharted territory.

And if you likened
this to the flu,

most people don't know
which flu vaccine they get.
In fact, there are several.
And they get what they get.

And that's because this is a
public health kind of solution.

And it's not that people
are offered up a choice.

So I think, in this
case, certainly

in the original,
the initial period,

certainly during emergency
use, my expectation would be

that there really isn't the
consumer choice in the matter.

There will be a limited
supply of vaccine.

And we will-- and
the government,

which will be in charge
of distributing it

both in the US and
other countries,

will in turn determine
basically how

to reach the various, initially,
most vulnerable population

and then, later on,
hopefully everybody.

So I would say the way to think
about it is based on data.

Because it's one thing to
think about the technology
underlying the vaccine.

It's nothing to look at
what proof points we have.

And upon successful completion
of a trial that actually does

show safety and efficacy
and then, of course,

you look at the second
layer of information,

there may be that
certain vaccines are
better for older populations.
We're certainly focused on that.

Because we recognize
this disease

is very much affecting
older populations.

So we're doing special sub
kind of category assessments.

We've already done
some in Phase I.

So I think over the
fullness of time,

more and more data
will come out.

And that may inform
decision making.

But for now, I think
it's going to be based
on supply and availability.

ADI IGNATIUS: So I know you
have to wait for these tests
to play out.

But what does your
gut say, in terms

of when Moderna will have
a product that can be used,

let's say, initially for
these most vulnerable groups
and then more generally?

And other people who are working
on a vaccine, what's your

guess as to when someone like
me, who's not in a risk--

high risk group, will be
able to have a vaccine?

ADI IGNATIUS: Look, I think
that that's a difficult thing

to speculate on with
great precision.

But what I can tell you is
that the public discourse

that certainly Moderna, Pfizer,
and others have engaged in,

as well as Operation Warp Speed
who has been publicly talking

about this, points to a
late November timeframe

before which there will be
enough safety data to now begin
to adjudicate efficacy data.

Because safety is a kind of
a barrier we need to hit.
And that's two months.

The FDA has said that they
want to see two months of data

minimally for the kind of the
50th percentile or patients
or subject that join.

So in other words,
when half of the people

have been given
their second dose

and we've waited two
months, that's the gate.

And that will happen
during the end of November.

Certainly from Moderna,
we've said this publicly,
and there may be other--

Pfizer may be in a
similar timeline.

Then it's a question
of, when are there

enough events recorded to be
able to make an adjudication?

And we expect that that might
be by end of November or maybe

a little sooner, which
is a bit of a moot point.

Because we have to wait
for safety or a bit later.

So in the kind of
November, early December

timeframe, that's the
best guess we can make.

But there are so many
unknowns and variables

that I think, especially in
a very expectant environment,

we'd be hard pressed
to try to add to that.

So I think the best
we could say is,

as we end up in late
November, December, we should
begin to get to [INAUDIBLE].

Now, you asked, how does
that transmit all the way
to kind of an average citizen?

And that I think is going to be
a matter of probably a couple,

three months before you get
through the emergency use

process and then a BLA,
what's called the BLA, which

is the formal FDA
approval for mass use

has to be adjudicated
on by the FDA.

And then the supply
begins to increase.

So probably we're looking
at spring, late spring,

by the time you have
more than adequate supply

to begin to penetrate
a broad population, not

just the early, most vulnerable,
and health care workers.
ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah.

So I want to ask you
one more question.

Then I'll bring in Josh
and Octavia who will ask,
I'm sure, much harder questions.

But, you know, I
got to ask, I mean,

developing vaccines
obviously is never easy.

It's not usually
done so quickly.

You know, you're under enormous
pressure for basic health
safety reasons.

But for political
reasons, you've

got an impatient government,
who is your purchaser,

and commercial reasons,
good news on results
can drive your stock price up.

How do you handle all of
these conflicting pressures,
as you do your job?

NOUBAR AFEYAN: Well,
look, I would say,

add to that the fact
that Moderna is a young,
9, 10-year-old company.

It's pursuing technology
that has no precedent,

has no academic precedent,
has no industrial precedent,
is brand new.

And obviously, we're a
company with no product, yet.

We have many, many
products in development.
But none that are commercial.

So yet more things to add to
the complexity and challenge.

Look, the answer is having
a team, leadership team,

led by the CEO Stephane Bancel,
Stephen Hoge, and others

on the leadership team, who
have a balance of the maturity,

the experience, the track
record, particularly having

run Moderna for
many, many years,

so this is the-- it's
one thing to have

theoretical kind of
experiences and another thing

to actually have done it
within the Moderna setting.

This is a company that went
from basically no products

in the clinic to 20 different
clinical programs ongoing,

did by far the largest
transactions in this industry,

whether it's financing
or partnerships.

And so we've been climbing up
a mountain for quite a while.

We never expected
that when we thought

we were getting close to
where we were shooting for,

there'd be a gigantic
mountain that

has touched upon us that
we've then, for public safety

reasons, not really
for financial reasons,
have to engage with.

But I would say the leadership
team, the platform importantly,

to me, it's really
important to understand,

most people think that biology
and biotechnology doesn't

lend itself to this kind
of platform investment.

Whereas, in Moderna's
case, it's an ideal example

of a common investment
that has given

rise to many, many products
and modularity of design.

So all of these things helped
us [INAUDIBLE] quickly.

But otherwise the pressures
are, you kind of keep your focus
on why you're doing this.

It is to [DOG BARKING]
[INAUDIBLE] of the suite of art

of solutions people have
as humanity to fight this.

And that purpose
kind of allows you

to prioritize what is noise,
what you have control over,

and what you can
communicate, and, you know,
kind of do it day-by-day.
ADI IGNATIUS: All right.

Let's bring-- let's
bring Josh and Octavia in
and have at the witness.
JOSHUA MACHT: Sure.
Noubar, nice to see you.
Take us back for a second.

I'm curious how it is that
you're defining efficacy.

What's the government
guideline versus what's

realistic for you, what you're
shooting for internally?
What does that really mean?

NOUBAR AFEYAN: Well,
look, I can say

what is public information,
just as a public company.

And what we have said is that
the governments guidelines
are the 50% kind of efficacy.

That is that you're
actually having

a differential effect
compared to placebo
to the 50th percentile.

100th percentile would be
that every single person who's

in the active did not-- does
not contract an infection

and the comparitive set
in the placebo does.

In this case, 50% is already
a pretty significant impact.

You can look at what
masks do and what

other things do under the
same basic comparative basis.
And so that's one thing.

But if you just look at,
well, what might happen?
It's hard to guess.

But there are vaccines that
are better than 95% effective.

There are some vaccines
that are 40%, 50% effective.

For example, the
seasonal flu vaccine

can be often in the
40% to 50%, 60% range.

And yet, we offer it for
administration to everybody.

And so I think we're still close
to letting the science guide us
that we will know.

But the notion
that a 50% vaccine

isn't worth taking but a
75% vaccine is I don't think

is consistent with the damage
this disease is doing broadly

and the impact it's having
not only on human health
but human activity and society.

I think all the
things it's doing

should cause us not to be kind
of very picky about just how
well it may be able to do.

I think we have a
real [INAUDIBLE]..
And so we'll know soon enough.

I would not rule out that
the very first vaccines are

a lot better than
what people expect,

nor do I want to create
that expectation.
It's just unknowable.
We will know.

And whatever we
have to deal with,

we will deploy as part of an
overall [INAUDIBLE] solution.

JOSHUA MACHT: I
mean the other part,

it's sort of amazing to think
that Moderna has kind of gone
as fast as they have.

If they-- and never, the company
has never developed a vaccine.

They're only a few
that really do.

And it's hard to
do it, almost feels

like winning the World
Series or something

in the first year,
first time in the league
if you pull this off.

Coming out of nowhere, make
sense of that for people

that it seems almost improbable
that you'd be able to do it.

NOUBAR AFEYAN: I mean, look,
it is true that on the surface

this could be an
overnight success ten
years in the making.

And I think that it is founded
upon a set of principles

and scaffolding, if
you will, that we

use to build our companies
across many, many companies.

I should say that
Moderna is part

of an ecosystem of companies
that today numbers about 40.

And historically, it's about
100 different companies

that we have been involved
within my firm Flagship

Pioneering in
conceiving, creating,

and helping with the management
team optimize and develop.
And I think that--

I'd like to believe
that that has helped

it be more than just
a random start-up that
might hit the lottery.

I think that's one of
the key considerations.

But as well the nature
of the science that we're

pursuing in the technology
is intrinsically modular,

is intrinsically a
kind of design-based,

as opposed to hit or miss kind
of find the small molecule that
might have an effect.

So I can get into
it in more detail.

But suffice it to say, those
of you who are interested

should really look up
[INAUDIBLE] technology.

This is the closest
thing to software.

If you liken the human body
to the hardware equivalent

of a computer,
software that allows

you to run a program that
is inject into a patient

a piece of code,
nothing more than code,

the same exact code,
different letter arrangement,
will make any protein you want.

In this case, we told it
to make the spike protein.

And the rest, the human
body takes care of.
How?

Because if you can
make cells in the body

make this spike protein
that the virus uses

to do a lot of its damage
and which is immunogenic,

we know that, then the
body's immune system

will go after the spike
protein without having
been exposed to the virus.
And you have an immune response.

So there are some things
that advantage our ability

to go quickly and
build on what we have
learned from the last decade.

I should say that whle
messenger RNA has not

been the basis of
any approved vaccine,

it has been in human trial
for 10 different vaccines
before COVID-19 came along.

And we definitely built upon
that background, as well as

NIH, I should also say,
who had been researching

this class of viruses,
these coronaviruses,

and, with us, had
been developing

a MERS vaccine, which was
getting close to getting
into human trials.

And it's the same team
and the same knowledge
that we repurposed for this.

So we were lucky in many
ways that all these precedent
conditions were there.

You have to be good
to get lucky, I guess.

And I think we were in
a pretty good position
to be able to get--

now again luck for us is even
being able to go this far.

To be honest with
you, I mean I--

we keep reminding each other
that what we've done so far
is highly unlikely.

And anything could stop us
from getting to the next step.

But even getting
this far, I think

was built on a
lot of prior work.
JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah, definitely.

OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: So I just
want to remind everyone

watching that we'll be answering
some of your questions.

So please do keep posting
them in the comments.

And Noubar, thank you for
everything you've shared.

As you know, I think
minority communities

have been disproportionately
affected by COVID-19.

And as you just outlined,
there are currently

30,000 participants enrolled
in your Phase III study.

Can you tell us what steps
were taken during enrollment

to ensure adequate
representation of minority
groups?

NOUBAR AFEYAN: Sure,
happy to Octavia.

And look, this was an
important issue for us,

maybe even more
important given that this

was our first, very first large
trial or even Phase III trial.

We'd never been in a Phase
III trial as an organization
before.

And we initially kind
of went about doing it

the way trials are generally
run in the biopharmaceutical
industry.

And what we found
early in our enrollment

in Phase III was
actually, not only
was there not a representative--

a population that is
representative of the US

population, but that there
was a particular kind of lack

of enrollment, particularly
from the Black population

that we felt alarmed by,
and then went and asked,
what happens in another trials?

And we found that, in general
5% to 7% of trial enrollments

often will be representative
of that minority.

And in general, there's
a problem there.
So we had a choice to make.

We could either
say, you know what?
That's not our problem.
Let's move on.
And let's get this trial done.

Or we could do a rather painful
decision that the management

team put forward with
its own initiative

and then with the board
to say, should we actually

slow down enrollment in order
to increase the representation
of minorities?

And should we further
tell our shareholders

that we're doing that,
at the expense of what

might seem to them as
delay, but what seems to us
as the responsible thing to do?

And I'm pleased to say
that, several weeks ago, we
did do that.

We slowed down enrollment from
the mainly white population

that have been volunteering
for these trials.

Of course, these
trials are being

done in many, many
different locations

where the virus was in a
hot zone, because we wanted

to be able to maximize the
chance of having affected
people in the trial.

Otherwise, we couldn't
read as to the effect
of the vaccine and the placebo.

And I'm glad to say that,
by the time we concluded

the trial, the numbers
of broadly minorities

and diversity represented
were over 35%, I believe 37%.

There was over 10% represented
from the Black population,

that was a doubling almost of
where we were in the beginning.

And the Hispanic
population ended up

being quite a large
population as well.

So we took steps we could
take it responsibly.

And I know that others
are doing likewise.

Some of the large pharma
companies, for example,

either have increased
the size of this trial
to achieve a similar goal.

So I think we're all
cognizant of this.

And we want to make this as
representative as possible.

And I think we
have a lot of work

to do as a country and
the health care system

to develop the enrollment
procedures that

will make these trials as
representative as possible.
OCTAVIA GOREDEMA: Yes.

So let's talk a bit
about the distribution
process of a vaccine.
Who gets it first and why?

And who makes those
tough decisions?

ADI IGNATIUS: Well, look,
this is a bit unprecedented.

But there have been prior
pandemics and prior situations,

not as large as this, that
at least guide the way.

This is something that,
in the current situation,

will be conducted through
the Operation Warp Speed,

this OWS entity
that's been created,

which is largely using
the military's logistics

capabilities to
ensure distribution

to a network of the providers
and further distributors.

And all of this
has been laid out.

The decision as to who gets
it will be largely a decision
that's made by the HHS, CDC.

The government will
put forward their list

of priorities and the
order in which they

expect under emergency
use that the vaccine will
be distributed.

And our responsibility will be
manufacturing, filling vials,

and handing over
to OWS our supply.

After that, and I'll say
parenthetically, thankfully,
we're not in that loop.

Because I wouldn't-- we
wouldn't know how to adjudicate
who's getting it.

And I'm happy that
the government

is playing its proper role,
as it is in other countries.

JOSHUA MACHT: So Noubar, I'm
also wondering if you can speak

to the difference between
emergency use that we've talked

about, which is what most of
the companies seem to be shoot--

going for, versus what the
FDA maybe is signaling around

expanded use and what that
might mean and why that--

what is that discussion
really all about?

NOUBAR AFEYAN: There is
an ongoing discussion

which I think is still kind
of early in its progress,

as to whether there's
alternatives to emergency use
that could be used.
And this is a kind of--

those of you who are
aficionados can follow this,

because there's been a
lot posted on Twitter

and other places
about these things

by experts and also
often non-experts

but to talk about
what an emergency use

authorization may do to the
treatment of placebo subjects.

Because once you have
a vaccine available,

is it ethically appropriate
to keep the placebo

group not knowing whether
it received vaccine or not?

And if you were actually
to break that placebo,

then what effect will it have
on the ultimate assessment

of the trial when it comes time
to a final biological license
application?

So these are technicalities
that are being discussed,
the threat on ethical issues.

And the FDA certainly
has been soliciting

input from different
posts about what else

should be done, how else--
everybody understands

that telling this country
with 1,000 dead every day

that it should wait another few
weeks so that we can do-- kind

of keep placebo in its place
and not issue emergency use

authorization if a
vaccine or more than one
